- Area (approx.): Asia ≈ 44.6 million km²; Africa ≈ 30.4 million km². Source examples: National Geographic, CIA World Factbook.
- Population: Asia first, Africa second.
- Number of countries: Africa has the most sovereign states of any continent (about 54).

Why parents might think otherwise
- Map distortion: Common Mercator projection maps enlarge northern landmasses (Greenland, Europe) and can make Africa look smaller relative to reality. Many people underestimate Africa’s true size.
- Different measures: People sometimes confuse “largest” meaning “most countries,” “most people,” or “biggest in public awareness,” rather than by land area.
- Ambiguity in wording: “Largest” without saying “by area” is ambiguous.

How to address this in your curriculum (practical suggestions)
- Teach the clear, age-appropriate fact: “Africa is the second-largest continent by land area (after Asia) and the second-largest by population. It has the most countries of any continent.”
- Include a globe or an equal-area map (Gall–Peters or other equal-area projection) and show Mercator vs. equal-area side-by-side to teach map literacy.
- Use hands-on activities: cut-out continent shapes and compare areas, use scale puzzles, or overlay transparent maps.
- Provide a short parent note or FAQ that states the facts and explains why some maps mislead, with sources (National Geographic, CIA World Factbook, UN population data).

How to respond to the parent group
- Acknowledge their concern.
- Provide the corrected factual statement and cite 1–2 reputable sources.
- Offer to update the textbook/handout language if it’s ambiguous or incorrect.
- Offer a brief parent information session or handout explaining map projections and why people are sometimes confused.

If you want, I can draft:
- A one-page parent letter explaining the facts and map distortion.
- A brief K–5 lesson plan or activity to teach this clearly and visually.
